title.narrative: Emergency food parcels to Syrian IDPs and affected people living in camps of in North eastern area in Syria .

description.narrative:
Syria is one of the largest protection crises of our time. Hundreds of thousands of civilians have been killed, and armed battles continue to carry out violations of human rights, with women and children particularly vulnerable to exploitation - including breaches of international humanitarian law.
Since the beginning of the crisis in 2011, Syria has witnessed significant challenges in the humanitarian and security situation across the country, leading to an increase of displacement that has had a negative impact on the IDPs and affected groups. Thus, countless of thousands of families left their damaged houses hoping to seek refuge in neighboring cities. In most cases, they leave without suitcases, personal belongings or money.
Several factors including international sanctions and massive inflation worsened the economy and public services and left industries and livelihoods paralyzed leaving millions of people completely aid dependent.
Most vulnerable communities, IDPs men and women, in particular women and youth, have fled to neighboring cities and villages in search for safety and security. Most of them lack the basic needs for survival, and this includes all basic needs. However, in Al-Hassakeh, most IDPs and affected people remained in the area due to the lack of income and constant dangerous situation they all were living in. Not to mentioned blocked road in and out of Al-Hassakeh which means the for the past at least 5 years, affected and vulnerable people living there did not have access to any basic need, that is now scarce to say the least. This project would therefore provide mid to long-term sustainable resilience to those most in need for NFIs.
The purpose of this project is to provide food parcels to people living in hard-to-reach areas like Al-Hassakeh. This will take place in locations where GOPA-DERD can have access, but one of its indirect goals is to help those with an urgent need for assistance.
According to 2017 HRP," Al-Hassakeh governorate currently hosts 231,951 internally displaced persons and 689,899 affected people in need of assistance. Most areas within the governorate remain restricted for humanitarian access. In May, as was the case in previous months, coping strategies to deal with a lack of resources commonly included reducing meal size, followed by borrowing money from family and friend and skipping meals. Extreme food-based strategies such as eating non-food plants, spending days without eating.
